content: Hi Iahching,  I suspect your doctor is just as frustrated as you are.  Occasionally, we have patients where we know something is going on but we can't "prove" it.  In your case, the elevated IgA protein levels and the abnormal plasma cells signal that there is something going on.  It sounds like the problem is that at this point a firm diagnosis cannot be made.  Because of this, a proper treatment cannot be chosen so the best thing to do is continue to follow up very closely with your doctor and wait for signs to appear that can make a definite diagnosis.   Close follow up is crucial so that the diagnosis can be made as early as possible.    Your foamy urine is likely due to increased protein levels in the urine.  Best wishes and I hope you are able to figure this out soon.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Myeloma in the brain......
content: Hello,  I hope your friend is doing well. Central Nervous System (CNS) involvement with multiple myeloma is extremely rare. It is diagnosed by finding malignant plasma cells in the spinal fluid by lumbar puncture. This is usually ordered after a patient with myeloma presents with CNS symptoms that are suspicious.   Usually these patients have advanced disease and various chromosomal abnormalities such as del 13q and p53 mutations. These abnormalities confer poor prognosis.  Unfortunately, there are two few cases to draw general conclusions about what may happen to your friend but most of these cases have been treated with CNS directed therapy (eg, intrathecal chemotherapy) as well as bone marrow transplants.  Sadly, most of the cases reported in the literature do not do well altogether. However, like I said there are too few of those and any generalization would be stated with caution.  Good luck!

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Abnormal Lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).   Sometimes, following infection Lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.   Bilateral and contralateral metastases from lateral tongue cancers are uncommon bu occur. I advise you to follow up with your doctor.  Keep us updated. Best regards.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear jenlyn95,  The 5-year survival rate for MM patients treated with conventional therapy is  20%-25% for those older than 65 years. About 30%-50% of  newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients are expected to be unresponsive to chemotherapy.  The criteria for partial response are: ■ > 50% reduction in serum myeloma protein ■ > 90% reduction in Bence Jones protein. Criteria for complete response include: ■ disappearance of serum myeloma protein and Bence Jones protein by immunofixation ■ no monoclonal plasma cells in bone marrow.  Thalidomide (Thalomid) can be uses alone and in combination with dexamethasone as upfront therapy in newly diagnosed patients. Thalidomide Alone, produces 50% reduction in paraprote in 36% of patients; and in up to 72% when given in combination.  Thalidomide shows superior results compared to dexamethasone alone but comparable to VAD (vincristine, Adriamycin [doxorubicin], and dexamethasone).   Care should be taken with any symptoms suggestive of thrombotic complications since high rateof thrombosis was found in patients receiving this drug.  Other regimens used for treatment of newly diagnosed MM patients are: -VAD (vincristine, Adriamycin [doxorubicin], and dexamethasone). -MP The combination of melphalan and prednisone has been used over the past 30 years but they cause damage to bone marrow cells and affect the bone marrow reserve. -Pulse dexamethasone alone is commonly used in patients who are going to receive Radiation therapy.  In those who are resistant e can be offered one of the following therapies:   - Combination Chemotherapy.  High doses of alkylating agents, alone or in combination are proved to be effective in these patients.  Examples of these regimens are:  IV melphalan (70-100 mg/m2)  The combination of high-dose cyclophosphamide (Cytoxan,  Neosar) and etoposide.   - Novel agents have shown good activity in the disease control and studies on these drugs are still going on, these agents include:  IMiD Revimid thalidomide analog with immunomodulatory effects.  Proteasome inhibition Bortezomib  Arsenic trioxide (Trisenox)  I advise you to follow with her doctor and to trust his judgment since he seems to be very careful in providing her the best  treatment options.  Best regrads,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear CEDWARDS,  Scrotal swelling are commonly due to extratesticular and intratesticular lesions.  Extratesticular lesions include: – Hydrocoele – Hernia – Epididymal cyst and spermatocoele – Varicocoele  Intratesticular lesions – Primary testicular tumour – Metastases, lymphoma and leukaemia – Testicular cysts and epidermoid cysts  Multiple myeloma is one of these cancers which can give metstatic lesions in the testis although not common.  US,  can distinguish between different causes of testicular and extratesticular origin, testicular tumors appear hypoechoic compared to normal testicular tissue. Focal or diffuse areas of homogeneous hypoechogenicity with sharply-demarcated intratesticular borders are the characteristic feature in some metastatic tumors like MM .  I advise you to follow up with his doctor for proper management.  Only by complete history, physical examination and investigations, the correct diagnosis can be reached.  Best regards,

author: alex.hardcastle  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Fri Feb 04, 2005 8:45 pm Location: Houston, Texas  Contact:   Contact alex.hardcastle       Website
title: Death and Dying
content: The process of death and dying is woefully ignored all too often at the clinical level. And if there is a way to answer your question with the certainty you seem to be looking for, it eludes me. Perhaps one of the other volunteers can offer their insight.  Bernie Siegel, MD, once told a large group of doctors in a conference setting that he would put up one-year of his salary against the one-year salary of any "taker" if the challenger could take a set of pathology reports from a cancer patient, and, predict within a 30-day window, either side of the actual date of demise, when the patient would die.  Despite there being about 200 well trained, experienced oncologists, hematologists and internal medicine specialists in the room, there was not a single taker. At that particular point in time, Dr. Siegel's salary ran to a seven-figure sum.  I have had a number of family membenrs tell me that they watched a loved one struggle against death, which is distinctly different that a patient struggling for life, until that person was told by family members that it was alright for them to pass on - after assuring them that it was, in essence, alright for them to die. Equally important though is the need to be mindful that an ill loved one must be supported in their decision to fight for their life.  If your mom has a living will, or any end-of-life type directives, and if she is truly incapable of making a decision about her wishes at this terribly straining moment, then family members are acting appropriately when they discuss the patient's wishes in this regard with the physician. Prolonging life functions for the mere sake of supporting bodily function is not always what the patient truly wants or even needs.  Having said that, let me hasten to add that hope is a cardinal emotion in all of us. Nothing should ever be done to quell the hope any patient at any time. If your mom is indeed trying to recover, perhaps even with the modest goal of just getting well enough to leave the hospital and pass away at home, I'd support her wholeheartedly in that, were she my mother.  In summary. patients described as being in a lot worse shape than you describe your mom have been known to recover, dramatically, and walk out of hospitals. Younger persons with fewer problems have been known to die without much warning.  I'd suggest listening carefully to your mother, get a good handle on her wishes, than support her as best you can.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello Lindah,  As you probably know multiple myeloma is a malignant disease of the plasma cells. The main function of these cells is to produce plasma proteins (immunoglobulins). Certain gene rearrangements lead to exessive production of plasma proteins via the malignant plasma cells leading to exess protein in blood and to many of the complications and manifestations of the disease.  As you respond to therapy (e.g. the radiotherapy you received) more malignant plasma cells die and this decreases the production of plasma proteins.  There are two types of complete remissions (CRs): a clinical CR and a molecular CR.   Criteria for clinical CR include disappearance of bony lesions in skeletal x-rays, normal plasma proteins, normal blood counts, normal electrophoresis and normal plasma cell rates on bone marrow examination.  Weight gain may be a result of therapy or due to renal affection (not in your case). Please get a lipid profile done to adjust your blood lipids and try to maintain a healthy diet if required.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Light chain
content: Angel,  Heavy and light chains can appear in the blood due to primary disorders (multiple myeloma is an example) but these can also be elevated due to a reactive state caused by other unrelated illnesses or problems affecting the body.  The C-reactive protein can be elevated in a reactive state as well.  Light chains are cleared by the kidneys and thus can appear in the urine and not so much in the blood.  You do not mention if any specialized testing was done on the blood or the urine to determine if the light chains seen are monoclonal (such is the case in multiple myeloma, for example) or "reactive".  How elevated were the light chains in the urine?  Amyloidosis produces similar proteins, although it is a different disease than multiple myeloma.  Sometimes the two disorders overlap.  If the light chain is slightly elevated in the urine and no monoclonality to it is seen, then I would repeat it.  If the blood does not reveal any monoclonal proteins, then still one needs to check the urine since if a blood disorder were to be present, then it may just produce light chains and not heavy chains.  The higher a heavy or light chain is detected and found to be monoclonal, the more likely that a multiple myeloma or related process is at play.  However, it is important to note that light chains can be elevated and not be monoclonal - again, this can be seen in a reactive state and does not imply a blood disorder.  If one wants to continue an evaluation for multiple myeloma or amyloidosis, then a bone marrow biopsy may be helpful.  For amyloidosis, a biopsy of a fat pad (such as near the belly button or near the rectum) can be done as well.  A Congo red stain will be positive in amyloidosis.  There are different forms of amyloidosis.  Can you post the results of your blood and urine tests?  That would be helpful.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Multiple myeloma
content: Thalidomide and the proteosome inhibitor (Velcade or bortezomib) are very interesting drugs.  Chemotherapy has remained standard therapies for myeloma, but not every patient responds and since a complete eradication of the disease without the use of a bone marrow or stem cell transplantation cannot be achieved, the myeloma at some time after treatment will grow again and become active.  Thalidomide each day is being used by itself or with high-doses of dexamethasone (40 mg) once a week.  I do use low doses of thalidomide (200 mg at bedtime each day) with dexamethasone in relapsed myeloma for patients who are not going for a transplantation.  Since most myeloma patients are elderly, transplantation is not an option.  Thalidomide can work well for extended periods of time.  It can cause constipation, sedation, and peripheral sensory neuropathy.  But at low doses at bedtime, these side effects are not severe and can be managed.  The high dose of the dexamethasone can cause GI side effects and there appears to be an increased incidence of venous thromboses when it is added to the thalidomide.  There is still some debate about this.  I do not routinely anticoagulate my patients with warfarin (some people recommend it), but I do watch closely for blood clots.  I do have my patients take a full strength aspirin.  Bortezomib  does have interesting activity in the thrid-line treatment setting of myeloma.  It is easy to give and is tolerated well.  There are many exciting studies looking at using thalidomide either with standard chemotherapy or dexamethasone as first-line treatment of myeloma.  Bortezomib is also being actively studied early in the course of the disease.  Overall, thalidomide and bortezomib have improved our ability to treat patients with multiple myeloma and it will be most exciting to see what develops with clinical research studies using these drugs.  Jeff Gordon, M.D.

content: Chromosome 13 changes can be seen in myeloma.  It is important to understand more than just chromosome 13 in myeloma.  Other factors such as the degree of the bone marrow involved by the disease, the height of the abnormal protein made by themyeloma, the statusof the kidneys, the presence of elevated calcium levels in the blood, and a patient's overall medical condition and age factor into what forms of treatment can be considered and used.  various chromosomal abnormailites in various hematological diseases can provide information about the disease and sometimes prognostic information.  It appears that the presence of a deletion of chromosome 13 carries a worse prognosis of themyeloma than if it is not present.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Gene mutation
content: Lynn,  Sorry to hear about your sister.  The gene mutation 20210 that you refer in the setiing of blood clots is the prothrombin G20210A mutation.  This gene mutation is seen in some patients who develop abnormal blood clots.  It is one of the more common gene mutations seen overall in patients who develop unexplained or abnormal blood clots.  The gene mutation can occur as having a "bad" copy of both genes (normally there are two "good" copies of the gene), which is termed homozygous.  Heterozygous refers to having one "bad" and one "good" copy of the gene.  The homozygous state carries a higher risk of developing clots than does the heterzygous state.  Usually, the risk is lowinf a person developing a clot if just the 20201 gene mutation is present.  In fact, the majority of such people are termed "silent carriers" in that they do not develop clots.  Some people never know that they have the gene mutation .  It is not routinely tested for.  Usually a person with the 20210 gene mutation develops a clot if another event or process occurs that also carries a risk of developing a clot.  For example, a person with the 20210 gene mutation may not develop a clot, but if a surgery or tramua occurs or a cancer occurs, then there is more than one process now at play to generate a clot and the risk profile increases.  As far as I know, there is no association between the prothrombin gene G20210A mutation and multiple myeloma.  Unfortunatley, both are not uncommon and can occur in the same person.  Myeloma can have associated with it an increased risk of clots, but this is not due to the prothrombin gene.  Some forms of myleoma treatment (for example, thalidomide with or without dexamethasone) can be associated with blood clots independent of the 20210 gene mutation.  If someone has the 20210 gene mutation, then it does not go away.  There is nothing per se that can be done to keep the "good" copy of the gene doing well.  The best that can be done is to provide prophylactic blood thinning only if an event is to occur (such as immobility after surgery) that will increase the overall risk of clotting.  I would assume that if you and your children have been tested for this gene mutation, that you have undergone genetic counseling.   If not, then you should talk with a Hematologist (a blood specialist) or a Genetic Counseolr.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D. Hematology-Oncology

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Multiple myeloma
content: Dr. Sohel,  Welcome!  Yes, unfortunatley, bisphosphonate therapy is expensive if someone does not have medical insurance, especially since the standard bisphophonates used in the treatment of multiple myeloma (at least in the U.S.) are given once a month on an indefinite time course.  The two FDA-approved bisphophonates that are used in the U.S. in this case are pamidronate and zoledronic acid.  The former has been used for a long time and is now in a less expensive generic form.  The latter is more potent, but in clinical trials comparing zoledronic acid 4 mg versus pamidronate 90 mg, both were equivalent.  It is not certain if the bisphophonate actually treats the myeloma, although there are intirguing laboratory findings and some clinical observations.  Nevertheless, it does significantly decrease the risk of hypercalcemia, bone fractures, and the debilitating complications of bone problems from myeloma.  I offer pamidronate 90mg once a month to my myeloma patients.  I consider it an important adjunct to  myeloma treatment, but the major part of myeloma treatment is the chemotherapy and/or steroids used.  I hope that this answers your questions.  Thanks for posting a question here at The Doctor's Lounge.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Multiple myeloma
content: Dr. Sohel,  Here in the U.S., we face as imilar problem with our patients who can not afford various treatments of the diseases.  In such cases, I have an honest talk with patients about their care and the cost of it.  There is a limit to how much free care we can provide.  If a patient wishes to hold on some part of treatment due to financial reasons, then that is their decision to make in an informed manne.   In the case of multiple myeloms, the important part of  treatment is 1.) chemotherapy, usually melphalan and prednisone or just dexamethasone therapy alone and 2.) control of any pain from the bones.  Bisphosphonates can help strengthen bones affected by myeloma, decrease the risk of developing bone fractures, and help with bone pain.  However, it does not replace chemotherapy or steroid therapy.  In the case of a patient who cannot afford treatment and wishes not to receive a bisphosphonate, then I proceed with just chemotherapy and/or steroid therapy, along with pain medications.  If the myeloma can be treated and kept under control for as long as possible, then the bone problems do improve, even without bisphosphonates.  Thank you for posting a question here at The Doctor's Lounge.  You are welcome to post a question any time and hopefully myself or someone else will be able to help you.  If you have any interesting cases that you would like to discuss, then let me know.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.[/quote]
